text:
It could be great to have some "signature capabilities" in the proxy. 

The typical scenario would be : 

1) Apache is a reverse proxy and receive a request
2) Apache add a header (like REMOUTE_USER)
3) Apache use a private key to sign the headers specified and put this value in a new header (like HEADERS_SIGNATURE). 
4) Target server behind reverse proxy can now trust the request and the header

Configuration could be 

HeaderSignatureTarget REMOTE_USER
HeaderSignatureStored REMOTE_USER_SIGNATURE
HeaderSignatureAlgorithm SHA1withRSA
HeaderSignaturePrivateKey file.pem

This means the that the apache will first evaluate the REMOTE_USER and sign this with the private key stored in file.pem using the algorithm SHA1withRSA. The header REMOTE_USER_SIGNATURE will be added to the forwarded request.

This could be a simple and efficient way of binding the reverse proxy to the target application server.

text:
mod_proxy can already encrypt and authenticate the whole connection with the backend using TLS.
Signing individual headers looks redundant...

creator: david.naramski@nowina.lu
text:
(In reply to Yann Ylavic from comment #1)
> mod_proxy can already encrypt and authenticate the whole connection with the
> backend using TLS.
> Signing individual headers looks redundant...

I want to protect the communication between the reverse proxy and the target server. 

I was not aware that it was possible to use mod_proxy to initiate a SSL Mutual Authentication between Apache and the target server. Do you confirm it is possible? 

I know that it is possible to use HTTPS but with this mechanism, the Reverse Proxy is not authentified.

(In reply to David Naramski from comment #2)
> I know that it is possible to use HTTPS but with this mechanism, the Reverse
> Proxy is not authentified.

Actually https allows client (mutual) authentication by requiring a client certificate on the backend side (see SSLProxyMachineCertificateFile/ChainFile/Path for the mod_proxy side).

text: You are right, my request is completely redundant with this mechanism.
